pr_title: [#353] Add tests to the neo4j quickstart

timeline.message:
Add tests to the neo4j quickstart

Signed-off-by: Miguel Serra <Miguel.Serra@criticaltechworks.com>

timeline.bodyText: Any reason to not use TestContainers as others quickstart (like Kafka)
timeline.author: cescoffier
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -73,6 +74,58 @@
           </execution>
         </executions>
       </plugin>
+      <plugin>
+        <!-- Automatically start Neo4J for integration testing - requires Docker -->
+        <groupId>io.fabric8</groupId>

replies.bodyText: Not really. I thought it'd be better to follow the hibernate quickstarts. I do prefer testcontainers, and didn't noticed it was used. I'll change it
replies.author: mcserra

replies.bodyText: The advantage of test container is that you can run the tests from your IDE or from your terminal.
replies.author: cescoffier

replies.bodyText: Ok, the changes are done. I don't think the changes can have something to do with the fail on the pipeline. Can we try and run it again?
replies.author: mcserra

replies.bodyText: I saw it, and the change is already done in the last commit, I was just asking if there is any other change that needs to be made...
replies.author: mcserra

timeline.bodyText: Would be great to also test the reactive API if possible.
timeline.author: cescoffier

replies.bodyText: I use it in line 60. Would it be better to create other test class? It doesn't have a persist method, so I did it in the same one
replies.author: mcserra

replies.bodyText: sorry, I didn't see it! that's great!
replies.author: cescoffier

timeline.bodyText: The interest of test container combined with this approach is that you don't need to set up the exposed port. It will pick a random available port.
timeline.author: cescoffier

replies.bodyText: I had a big problem to make it work with the native test, and found that solution. But I just tried it again without that and it worked, so I must have made a mistake...
